div.head: Question 50
Whether some proposition is able to be composed from the intentions and species naturally signifying in the some external thing.
div.p: Whether some proposition is able to be composed from the intentions and species naturally signifying in the some external thing.

One says that here that there is a double mental propositions in the soul, one corresponding to the vocal proposition, and another corresponding to the written proposition, which differ in species because it is impossible that one thing is a natural likeness
of two things distinct in species because a natural likeness and that of which it is a likeness are of the same species. But a mental proposition and a written proposition differ in species, therefore. Through a similar reason it is proven that the mental propositions differ in species which nevertheless correspond to the propositions in writing because many propositions in writing differ in species because some are in stone, some in wood. But all mental propositions corresponding to vocal words are of the same species.

Again, according to them, no mental proposition should be posited unless it is composed from terms which are natural likenesses of the written or mentioned terms. Whence from the species which they posit, the natural likeness of things, like of man and things of this type, no proposition is composed, but only from terms which are natural likeness of what is vocalized or written which terms indeed signify things ad placitum, which are signified through vocalized words or what is written, though these utterances and things written signify naturally. And therefore every mental propositions in the whole world corresponds, according to him, to some idiom or to something written.

And from this he concludes that this description of a mental term is not valid because the mental term is an understanding or passion of the soul signifying something able to be part of a mental proposition because such terms are not parts of the mental proposition. This opinion is argued thus, a terminus signifies nothing naturally because in the definition of the name and word it is the case that it signifies ad placitum, see book 1 of the Peryhermenias. It is said there that name and word are defined in one voice.

On the contrary: to the logic it is pertinent to determine about the proposition and the mental term attributes to these, and these does not happen elsewhere, therefore it happens there. Furthermore, though the one defining man intendes to define true man and not an fictiious man, nevertheless just as fictious man is called man improperly, so it is called a rational animal improperly. Similarly, though he intends there to define such things in voice, nevertheless if the things defined are found in the intellect, then the definitions are suitable to them, therefore every mental names signifies as desired.

Again, everyone experiences in themselves that they are able to form such propositions before they speak them and signifying the terms as desired, whence the one who knew the Latin forms Latin propositions.

Again, to every word/noun corresponds to a mental propositions, therefore to this term being corresponds being is one, therefore a mental term corresponds to the subject which naturally signifies everything. The consequent is false because that something is the natural sign of something only happens in three ways because either is the cause of it or the effect of it or the natural likeness of it, none of which belong to the mental term with respect to every thing.
Again, the pilgrim forms this: God is three and one, therefore the mental term corresponding to the subject will be a natural sign of God.

Again, regarding the subject of that proposition in the mind, every quality which would inhere in the subject, would be a natural likeness of every quality, which is impossible because by virtue of the fact that it is a natural likeness of one it is a natural dislikeness of the other.

Again, it is the case concerning the ratio of the word that it understood from what is informing, but when I form the word color, no one experiences having the word of contrary things and natural likeness of the same thing, therefore etc.
Again, having posited a single word of whiteness, the intellect is able to form the following, whiteness is whiteness, therefore there are two natural likeness of all whitenesses.

But against this opinion is
Anselmus Monologion 31
saying thus:
it is not able to be denied by any reason when the rational mind understands itself, the image of itself is born in its cognition; indeed that this cognition of itself
is the image of itself for its likeness, as if formed from an impression of it
Anselm, Monologion, c. 33
.

Therefore such a likeness born in the soul is truly of the same species with it, then it follows that any soul would produce and infinity of rational souls, and when the rational soul creations in this mode alone, it follows that the soul is able to create.
Again, the species of human being is in the mind of the angel, but the species of human being is a human being, therefore.

Again, there were many men who had neither a father or a mother, who never ate or drank , and nevertheless they remained from the beginning of the world, nor are these men able to laugh, and as a consequence they are not risible, nor will God every judge them because these men, who are in the human species, will never die and are not mortal.
Again, the inferior angel understands the superior, therefore it has in itself the more noble angel itself because it has this species.
Again, for as many phoenix, as many suns, as many moons, there are as many intelligences for phoenix, son, and mood.
Again, if God were to annihilate all bodies of the word, there would still be many men and many lions in the mind of angels.
Again, many men were create before Adam because in the angelis there were the species of men co-created before Adam.

Again,
color is the limit of the transparent in a terminated body
Aristotle, De sensu et sensato, xxx
De sensu et sensato, chapter 6 , and II De anima
it is said that
color is est the lighted moving according to act
, therefore color is truly seen in the brain.
Again, every heavy thing naturally descends, but the species of a stone in the mind of an angel is heavy, therefore why does it no descend?

Again, either the species of a stone in the soul or in an angel is a corporeal substance or incorporeal. If incorporeal, then it is not a body. If corporeal, then the biggest stone is naturally in a ???? space.

Again, Aristoteles says that
The stone is not in the soul, but the species of the stone
Aristotle, De anima, III.8 (431b29-432a1)
, which is false according to this opinion.

Again, in II
De anima, in comment 104 ,
if what is seen were to have color in act, then it would not receive other colors
Averroes, In de anima, II, commento 104 (Juntina, vol. XI, Venice 1562, 105r A)

Again,
Augustinus, 10 Confessionum, in chapter 15 et 16
XXXX
, says that the image of sadness is in the memory and nevertheless not sadness.

Nevertheless for this opinion, he puts many opinions.
II De anima, in comment 57
color has a double being
Averroes, In de anima, II, commento 76 (Juntina, vol. XI, Venice 1562, 89v F)
, namely colored in the body, and this is corporeal, and in the diaphanous medium, and this is spiritual.

Again, 7 Metaphysics, in comment 23
health is said about the understanding of health which is in the soul, and about the health which is in the body, and the health, which is in the body, is from the health, which is in the soul , and in the same comment he says
the form of skill is twofold, one which is in the soul, and another which is outside, and the are the same.

Again in
11 Metaphysics
Averroes In metaphysica XII, commento 36 (editio Juntina secunda, vol. VIII (Venezia, 1562), 318va I)
, concerning a bath in the soul, etc.

He also puts the same that cognition is a cognitive potency which is the soul itself. Whence human cognition is nothing unless the soul knowing. Nevertheless, this term cognition, as he says, when it is taken for a thing by which the one knowing, is formally the one knowing. Sometimes it is taken for the likeness (similitudine???) of the known thing, and sometimes for the thing known. In the first mode it is called formal cognition, in the second mode material or objectively immediate, in the third mode, material or objectively mediate.

Again, he distinguishes this term cognitive because when it is taken as the efficient cause of cognitions, sometimes it is for what is receptive of cognition, sometimes for that by which something is formally able to be known.

Therefore his first conclusion is this: every human cognition taken in the first mode is a cognitive potency. This is proved thus, if cognition were a quality super-added through divine potency, it would be able to put in a stone, and thus what is not-cognitive would know. Nor is it valid to say that this quality is not able to be a formal perfection of the stone because human nature is in the divine person and nevertheless does not perfect it formally and this not withstanding he names it formally according to its
properties.

Again, color is formally seen through vision, therefore, when color and vision are conserved, it will always be true: color is seen, therefore, having destroyed the visible potency, this will be true, true color is seen.

Item quando aliquid est aliquale per aliud illud aliud est per se tale setpotentia cognitiva est formaliter cognoscens per cognitionem ergo cognitio formaliter seipsa cognoscit igitur destincta potentia cognitiva sive intellectiva intellectio intelligeret

Item impossibile est praedicamenta contradictoria respectiva verificari successive de aliqua re nulla facta mutatione circa rem de qua verificantur nec circa rem cuius verificatur set ista praedicata intellectio non intellectio sunt praedicata contradictoria respectiva ergo impossibile est illa verficari de qualitate quae dicitur intellectio nulla facta etc etc igitur si destruatur potentia intellectiva et conservetur obiectum et qualitas habent vera si foretur haec qualitas est intellectio

Item impossibile est effectum esse perfectiorem sua causa efficiente set cognitio est quandoque perfectior obiecto cognito et potentia cognitiva si est res distincta a potentia cognitiva igitur nec potest causari ab obiecto nec ab obiecto
Dicitur quod causatur ab utroque et non ab altero ut a causa totali sed partiali tantum

contra illa cognitio est divisibilis vel indivisibilis si indivisibilis igitur a quocumque producitur totaliter producitur alioquin idem vis produceretur et una causa superflueret ex quo producitur totaliter ab altera si divisibilis ergo cum nullum divisibile sit in infinitum divisibile ut dicit ille sic opinans sequitur quod est devenire ad cognitionem indivisibile et de illa quaerendum est aut causatur totaliter ab obiecto vel non etc
Item si omne cognitivum in homine sit potentia cognitiva set alia cognitio hominis est cognitiva ergo alia cognitio hominis est potentia cognitiva

Item iste terminus cognitivum vel dicit causam effectivam materialem vel formalem vel finalem non primum quia sic vel foret cognitivum nisi quod actualiter cognosceret nec 2o nec 4o modo ut patet ergo 3o modo et per consequens idem quod est cognitivum est cognitio quando actu aliquis cognoscitur ergo intellectio est potentia intellectiva

Item si aliquid sit causatum a re visa vel igitur agit aequivoce vel univoce si univoce igitur sunt eiusdem rationis et sic paries alba videret sua albedine et sic falsum repraesentaretur quia quando duae qualitates sunt eiusdem speciei et alia res fuerit aliqualis per unam reliquam erit talis per reliquam si agens est aequivocum aut visio est perfectior vel inperfectior si perfectior igitur effectus foret perfectior sua causa efectiva
si imperfectior igitur foret visio imperfectior albedine consequens falsum dicitur quod causatur ab obiecto et potentia receptiva

contra sic possem ego fingere quod nulla qualitas causatur ab obiecto extrinseca set contra est commentator 2o de anima commento 140 sicut actio passio sunt in patiente non in agente ita actio sensum et sensibilium sunt in sensibilitate ex quo patet intentio

Item si intentio sit qualitas superaddita sit illa a volo igitur quod cognoscens cognoscat a aut igitur ipso a aut alia intellectione cognoscit a si alia erit processus in infinitum si seipsa igitur eadem ratione etc confirmatur per augustinum 2 de trinitate capitulo 4 ipsa visio non est aliud quam sensus qui videt esse videtur hoc est visio non est aliud esse videtur quam sensus informatus specie

ad ista tamen Respondetur ad primum conceditur totum usque ibi cognitivum intelligit quod nemo quia non cognitivum non est cognitio nec denominat aliquid cognoscens nisi quando est in natura cognitiva etiam eodem modo
pono contra eum pono quod deus ponat animam informatam specie in lapide et tunc habet ille conclusionem concedere quia non plus requiritur per eum ad hoc quod una res denominet aliam nisi quod sit in distans ab ea
Item deus est in lapide et deus est intellectio igitur etc et tamen falsum est dicere quod lapis intelligit igitur
Item intellectio est in pede quia anima et tamen pes non intelligit
Item haec consequentia non est formalis lapis intelligit igitur non cognitum intelligit quia tantum est consequentia ut nunc quia si deus assumeret lapidem antecedens esset verum et consequens falsum
// ad 2m dico eodem modo quia illo casu posito illa qualitas non foret visio quia iste terminus visio supponit pro una quantitate connotans eam esse in certo subiecto
ad 3m dico quod una causa non denominat aliam nisi forte denominatione extrinseca nihil enim est dictum actio formalis vel materia finalis

ad 4m dico quod stante illa specie in anima anima quandoque est intellecto quando non / Similiter assumit falsum quia volo quod circulus significet ibi esse vinum ab hora prima usque ad horma 9am et non ultra tunc signum et non signum sunt praedicata respectiva contradictoria Similiter rex facit quod denarius est nunc praetium panis et prius non fuit et tamen nec panis mutatur nec denarius sicut deus creat animam platonis in a et tunc nec deus mutatur nec anima
ad aliud dico quod dicimus hanc conclusionem esse demonstrativam non quia demonstrat nec habitum electivum quia elegit set quia homo eligit per illum

ad aliud dico quod anima secundum eum est cognitiva et anima est cognitio nam iste terminus cognitivum dicit causam formalis cognitionis quaero de illa causa vel est cognitio vel alia res si alia cognitio est opposita

alia conclusio eius est haec Similitudo cognoscentis quae est naturalis similitudo qualitatis sensibilis extra cognoscitur et senseritur non cognita re cuius est similitudo patet per motionem circularem virgae ignitae in cuius extremitate videtur circulus igneus set nullus talis circulus est extra videntem cuius causa naturalis ut dicit est illa quia color unius partis virgae existens in uno situ causat similitudinem suam in capite videntis et in alio situ existens causat aliam quae conterminatur similitudinem praecedenti in capite et in 3o loco 3am quibus sic conterminatis fit unus color circularis qui manet in capite videntis toto tempore mensuratae circulationem praedictam et ideo apparet videnti quod pars illa sit similis in quocumque situ circulationis ideo in casu illo nullum circulum ignitum videt set tantum similitudinem
Set contra tunc oportet quod talis similitudo in visu foret tantae quantitatis quantae videtur sibi quod est unus circulus extra videre negatur consequentia cuius causa est quia videns colorem extrinsecum per eius speciem sub eodem angelo videt speciem et colorem cuius est et ideo species et color apparent videnti eiusdem quantitatis quia videntur sub eisdem agnulis scilicet aequalibus

Alia conclusio est haec Similitudo naturalis Rei cognitae est eiusdem speciei cum re illa cuius est et haec est opinio Rogeri bakum in sua perspectiva distinctione 6 capitulo 3o probatur haec sic impossibile est una qualitatem esse naturalem similitudinem alterius a differt specie quia non habemus aliud medium pro statu isto ad probandum quod duae res sunt eiusdem speciei nisi quod una est naturalis similitudo respectu alterius igitur etc
2o sic albedo visa causat speciem vel igitur est agens univocum et habetur propositum vel aequivoce quod est falsum quia in generatione aequivoca effectus est dissimilis agenti
Item omne visibile est lux vel color set illa species est visibili quia sic videtur ergo est lux vel color non lux quia illa non naturalis similitudo colorum est igitur est colore

Item respiciens attente colorem viridem et subito se vertens ad obscurum adhuc videt colorem viridem set nullum extra igitur ille color est in vidente et eiusdem speciei cum colore prius viso et idem sentiendum est de specie intelligibile et de re a qua generatur

Item 2o de anima si visus haberet colorem in actu non reciperet colores quia igitur non recipit colores non habet colores in actu non tamen negat quin habet in potentia propter istas rationes concedit opinans quod tam angelus quam anima est aliquando frigidus aliquando calidus et lapis est cum angelo in caelo et in anima quando cum intelligit lapidem
Et si arguitur contra impossibile est duas formas materiales esse eiusdem speciei cum forma materiali
Item impossibile est duas formas eiusdem speciei simul esse in eodem subiecto sed duae similitudines quarum una causatur ab una albedine et alia ab alia in eodem occulo sunt etc
Item lapis non est in anima set species lapidis
Item si beatus videret deum mediate specie produceret aliquid eiusdem speciei cum deo

ad primum dicitur quod forma dicitur in materia tripliciter vel quia illud est indivisibile et per oppositum forma materialis est divisibilis et quaelibet forma divisibilis Alio modo quia est in subiecto materiali et per oppositum materiale dicitur quaelibet perfectio sibi materialis 3o modo dicitur forma in materialis quae naturaliter separatur a naturalia et materiale per oppositum primo modo et 2o forma materialis et immateriali sunt eiusdem speciei // 3o modo vel loquimur de forma substantiali vel accidentali primo modo non sunt eiusdem speciei 2o modo sunt quia color in mente angeli etc
Ad 2m concedo quod duae formae possunt simul esse in eodem subiecto
Ad 3m aristoteles ibi vocat speciem lapidis similitudinem accidentis lapidis
ad 4 impossibile est intellectum creatum formare verbum de deo

Contra primam conclusionem et probo quod non sufficit ad hoc quod anima intelligat solum anima et species set requiritur 3a res quae dicitur intellectio quia fiat quod sortes non intelligat platonem et tamen quod species platonis sit in memoria sortes et per consequens in anima sortes igitur aliqua res requiritur

Item visu se habente universaliter ad obiectum in prima parte temporis in casu videt in 2a non posito quod in 2a parte anima fuerit multum intenta circa aliquid cognoscibile ut patet etiam de distractis quaerentibus quod habent primi occulis

contra ultimam conclusionem sic quando duae qualitates sunt eiusdem speciei et aeque intensae si sunt activae possunt esse inaequalem et aeque intensas operationem set calor in igne et eius species sunt huius igitur etc
